_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY POLICY

The owners, management and employees of The DeLong Co., Inc. are committed to the
prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Through training local emergency  
responders and employees.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work
with the local fire department or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. 

FACILITY INFORMATION
The DeLong Co., is  a member of the Fertilizer 100.  Meaning they are one of the largest 100
fertilizer dealers in the nation and one of the biggest in Wisconsin.  They employ more than 85
people company wide. There are actually five divisions in The DeLong Co., Inc. Chick DeLong
is in charge of feed.  Bo DeLong is in charge of grain.  Dan DeLong is in charge of Delco
Transport.  Steve Quade is in charge of the seed division.  David DeLong, President, is in charge
of fertilizer and chemicals. The primary activity at the facility is the storage, distribution and
application of anhydrous ammonia for stateline area farmers. The maximum quantity stored
would be 140,196 pounds in our 30,000 gallon storage tank. The maximum quantity handled
would be the unloading of a rail tank car holding 150,000 pounds.

WORST - CASE

The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the entire contents of a storage tank or
tank car released as a gas over 10 minutes. The maximum quantity released would be 150,000
pounds which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent of capacity as
limited by design standards. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 1.1
miles.

ALTERNATIVE-CASE

The alternative release scenario based on the five-year accident history or the most likely
potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose. The distance to the endpoint (point
of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 01 miles.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety

Requirements" for the storage and
handling of anhydrous ammonia, K-61.1 published by the American National Standards Institute
Inc. and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29
CF 1010.111 storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia and the company random safety spot
check.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The following is a list of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five-years that
have occurred at the facility. 4/20/98 14,000# released, several adjacent business were
evacuated for a sort time, about 50 people. One person injured, none hospitalized. To our
knowledge, there were no offsite deaths, injuries, sheltering in place, property damage or
environmental damage.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE

The company has it's emergency response unit and team ready for any accidental releases of
anhydrous ammonia plus a written emergency action plan in accordance with OSHA standard 29
CFR 1191 D.38

We provide state and local authorities the emergency planning and community sight-to-know
information as required under Sara Title III EPCRA and  a written emergency response program in
accordance with OSHA standard 29CFR 1910.20 including pre-emergency planning and
employee training.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on going process at The DeLong Co. Inc. Periodic evaluation are
performed to access the maintenance and safety conditions. There are no additional specific
anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
